title: Demonstrate the advantage of modular programming, due to:
Using subprograms, procedures, and scope (private vs public).
Describing an algorithm written using modular programming.

To demonstrate these outcomes, I’d like to write an algorithm to allow two players to play Connect-Four using modular programming, and walk you through the benefits and mechanisms of a modular program.
Untitled
caption: Connect 4 - a popular and immensely enjoyable if simple game.

title: 1. demonstrate an understanding of modular programming
b
i

1.1 describe the advantages of programming with modules or subroutines including:
1.1.1 reducing the duplication of code in a program
1.1.2 enabling the reuse of code in more than one program
1.1.3 decomposing complex problems into simpler pieces to improve maintainability and
extendibility
1.1.4 improving the readability of a program
1.1.5 hiding or protecting the program data
1.2 select a programming environment and describe how it supports procedural programming
including:
1.2.1 the type of subprograms supported; e.g., procedures, functions, methods
1.2.2 the level or type of modularity provided
1.2.3 the level of protection provided from unwanted side-effects.

Modular programming reduces bloat by allowing programmers to make commonly used lines of code subfunctions. If a code snippet is used twice in the program, one can instead embed that snippet into a function and call it twice.
Abstraction — breaking down complex problems into simpler subtasks
Nobody wants to write a two-hundred-line block of code. Submerging subprograms into functions makes it easier to conceptualize the entirety of the program while programming it.
Having functions with self-explanatory names can add an incredible amount of clarity to a program. When another programmer reads a function named
check_for_win()
i
, they’ll understand what it does without diving into the exact code of the check_for_win function.
Obscuring functions that contain private information — some aspects of the program can be kept behind a secure API.

It’s often wise to keep some parts of a program away from a user for security, quality of life, and privacy reasons. Modular programming allows a developer to divide their programs into subprograms — and keep the subprograms using sensitive information, like password authentication, on secure hosted servers behind an API.
C++ supports function and object declarations. In practice, this means that developers can create their own custom subfunctions, place them in libraries (called header files), and call them.

of
input

for both inputs)
string myFunction(int input_1, int input_2){ // Note that I have to specify the
type

string

C++ supports programs with
both high and low
b
levels of
modularity, coupling, and cohesion
b
. At the highest level of modularity, C++ supports dividing a program into different
.cpp
i
files, each with its own functions and structure. At its lowest, it allows the developer to write the entire program within the
main()
b

function of one file, which is known as the “big ball of mud” approach and is generally not recommended. 

Levels of
coupling
b

in C++ are completely up to the programmer, with lower levels of interconnectivity achieved by having fewer inter-file and inter-program imports and calls and with high levels of interconnectivity achieved by the opposite.
Cohesion
b
is achieved by having functions mostly be self-contained, with all or most of the code required for its function within it.
For our Connect-4 program, we’d love to have
high modularity, high cohesion, and low coupling.
b
C++ is a mid-high level language, which means it has less protection against unwanted behaviour than high-level languages like Python and Typescript, as it is a…
Compiled language.
b
There are two major groups of languages today:
compiled
b
and
interpreted
b

programming languages:

Interpreted languages (such as Python) run code
line-by-line
b

, and will throw an exception if an illegal command is used. Illegal commands include accessing an index of a list that is larger than the list and dividing by zero. 

Compiled languages instead only check for syntax errors (misspellings, calling functions that don’t exist) before
compiling the program into an executable.
b

Once compiled, the executable gives little to no feedback if an error occurs, and will happily execute illegal commands — accessing other parts of your memory that it extrapolates should contain the nonexistent part of the list, or returning an extremely large number after dividing by zero.
Thus, the onus is on the developer (us) to ensure that the program runs as intended and doesn’t contain any logic or runtime errors, which C++ cannot check for.
2. demonstrate basic procedural programming skills by writing algorithms employing a modular approach to solve problems
b
i

2.1 analyze a data processing problem and use a top-down design approach to decompose it into discreet input, processing and output modules
2.2 analyze and refine modules into submodules that are a manageable size for each process; e.g., input submodules, processing submodules and output submodules
2.3 describe and represent, using pseudocode or an appropriate diagramming approach, the relationship among the modules

2.4 analyze and rewrite algorithms for each module identifying the pre- and post-conditions and required program control of flow mechanisms.
2.5 analyze and evaluate algorithms for each developing module with appropriate data and revise, as required.
Connect-4. Before we begin, we must set the scope of the project. What should it include?
A
graphical user interface
b
for the players to see the current board state
Move logic
b
— players should be able to choose a column to play a piece in, and see that change reflected on the board.
Win checking
b
— the game stops when a draw, win, or loss occurs.
Start of the game — the character they’d like to use for their pieces (e.g “x” or “o”).
Every move — a number from 1-7, specifying the column to play a piece of their color into.
In the case of an illegal move — a number from 1-7 to specify another move that is valid.
Game over — a yes/no input regarding whether to play the game again.
Input: An array containing the positions of the pieces on the board.
Output: A visual representation of the board state.
Input: An array containing the positions of the pieces on the board | the current player | the column that the piece is played into.
Output: An updated version of the board reflecting the change.
Input: An array containing the positions of the pieces on the board
Output: A numeric code representing the current condition of the board — 1 if player 1 wins, 2 if player 2 wins, 0 if tie, and -1 if game is still ongoing.
Input: Piece position array, column to check
Output: If it’s valid to play in that column.
The functions are
weakly coupled and strongly cohesive —
b
they
don’t call upon each other
b
. Only the main loop calls upon the functions.
3. translate algorithms into source code, convert the source code into machine executable form, execute and debug, as required.
b
i

3.1 convert an algorithm into a program of linked subprograms with a main or client module calling other modules in a manner that reflects the structure of the algorithm
3.2 use appropriate types of subprograms to implement the various sections of the algorithm; e.g.,functions (subprograms that return a value) and procedures (subprograms that do not return a value)
